text: But, but clearly there are, there are patterns that come from, from at least mathematics that, that do not have the conventional kind of explanation that biological patterns have So how much of this is actually relevant to biology So, so, so biologists hate this idea because they want a nice kind of sparse ontology where you have, you have the physical world and that's it And they don't want any, you know, any, any weird stuff But I think a lot of mathematicians are actually pretty comfortable that what they're doing is exploring a completely different world that is not in fact explained by any fact of Physics, it matters for physics
primary_topics: Ontological Differences between Biology and Mathematics
Role of Physics in Biological and Mathematical Patterns
content_summary: The speaker discusses the unconventional nature of mathematical patterns in biology, highlighting the ontological differences between the perspectives of biologists and mathematicians. The role of physics in explaining these patterns is also mentioned.
